required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Work Ability in Young Adult Survivors
clinical_study.official_title: Work Ability in Young Adult Survivors (WAYS)

brief_summary.textblock: To document levels of labor force participation, occupation, educational attainment, and financial toxicity following cancer treatment in YA cancer survivors aged 25-34 years.

detailed_description.textblock: This observational, cross-sectional study will recruit 200 YA survivors through the Wake Forest National Cancer Institute Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) Research Base (WF NCORP RB). Data will be collected using a web-based interface and will capture physical, psychosocial and cognitive late effects; work ability; work-related outcomes, including labor force participation, occupation, work place characteristics, and educational attainment; survivor characteristics; and cancer diagnosis/treatment information (from clinical records). We will evaluate the relationships among these measures using the theoretical framework to guide statistical analysis.

primary_outcome.description: Items selected from self-report measure of current work ability compared to lifetime best, physical and mental demands of job, impact of illness on work ability, and perceived future work ability.
Self-report measure of impact of chronic health conditions/treatment on job performance
8-item self-report measure of memory, concentration, and executive function over past 7 days.
8-item self-report measure of concerns regarding speed of thinking, difficulty in maintaining attention, and impact of mental mistakes on quality of life in the past 7 days.
Brief self-administered, online cognitive assessment of 4 neurocognitive domains: processing speed, attention, working memory and visual learning memory.

29-item self-report measure including 4 items each for the following domains: physical function, anxiety, depression, fatigue, sleep disturbance, social function and pain interference; plus 1 item measuring average pain intensity. Physical and social function domains assess current function; items for all other domains reference the past 7 days.

Self-report measure of capability for physical activities (i.e., walking/mobility and instrumental activities of daily living). Assesses current function. Will use only the 4 items that are unique to this measure (will not duplicate the 4 items already included in PROMIS-29)
11-item self-report measure of financial distress experienced in response to cancer and its treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: NIH Toolbox - Positive Affect, Life Satisfaction, Meaning & Purpose
primary_outcome.description: 4-item short form for positive affect, 5-item short form for life satisfaction, and 4-item short form for meaning and purpose.
8-item self-report measure of self-perceived success in important areas such as relationships, self-esteem, purpose, and optimism. The scale provides a single psychological well-being score.
10-item measures of self-reported positive psychological changes following a highly stressful experience.
Module developed for GSS, a high-quality, widely-used survey . The items address current job characteristics, employment conditions and work environment.
8-item self-report measure of amount of support received/satisfaction with support from supervisor from Nordic Study on Cancer and Work.

arm_group.description: Data collection: brief cognitive testing; detailed questionnaire assessing occupation, education status, a variety of work measures, and self-reported physical, psychosocial, and cognitive function; medical history, cancer treatment information, and medication use.

Data collection: brief cognitive testing; detailed questionnaire assessing occupation, education status, a variety of work measures, and self-reported physical, psychosocial, and cognitive function; medical history, cancer treatment information, and medication use.

Data collection: brief cognitive testing; detailed questionnaire assessing occupation, education status, a variety of work measures, and self-reported physical, psychosocial, and cognitive function; medical history, cancer treatment information, and medication use.

Data collection: brief cognitive testing; detailed questionnaire assessing occupation, education status, a variety of work measures, and self-reported physical, psychosocial, and cognitive function; medical history, cancer treatment information, and medication use.

intervention.description: Brief cognitive testing; questionnaire assessing occupation, education status, variety of work measures, self-reported physical, psychosocial and cognitive function; medical history, cancer treatment information and medication use.

study_pop.textblock: YA survivors between ages 25-34 were selected because they are relatively early in their career trajectory and represents AYA cancer survivors. This age range allows comparison to national benchmarks on work-related outcomes as it matches exactly the age range examined in the national employment statistics. We chose 2 years post diagnosis to allow time for acute effects of cancer treatment to stabilize and because many survivors are likely to have returned to work. The 10-year post-diagnosis cap limits confounding between time since treatment and current age. We will accrue to 4 cells in equal numbers (N=50 for each cell)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 25-34 years of age at time of participation
- 2 to <10 years post-cancer diagnosis (per diagnostic pathology report).
- Diagnosed with first cancer (any type except types listed in exclusion criteria below) at age â‰¥15 years.
- Ability to understand and willingness to sign a written informed consent document.
- Must be able to read and understand English and/or Spanish.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Currently receiving active cancer treatment (acceptable to be on maintenance or hormonal therapies).
- Life expectancy less than 6 months
